sn35.155:1.1: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha … and asked him,
sn35.155:1.3: How is a Dhamma speaker defined?”
sn35.155:2.1: “If a mendicant teaches Dhamma for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding the eye, they’re qualified to be called a ‘mendicant who speaks on Dhamma’.
sn35.155:2.2: If they practice for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding the eye, they’re qualified to be called a ‘mendicant who practices in line with the teaching’.
sn35.155:2.3: If they’re freed by not grasping by disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding the eye, they’re qualified to be called a ‘mendicant who has attained extinguishment in this very life’.
sn35.155:2.4: If a mendicant teaches Dhamma for disillusionment with the ear … nose … tongue … body …
sn35.155:2.5: mind, for its fading away and cessation, they’re qualified to be called a ‘mendicant who speaks on Dhamma’.
sn35.155:2.6: If they practice for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding the mind, they’re qualified to be called a ‘mendicant who practices in line with the teaching’.
sn35.155:2.7: If they’re freed by not grasping by disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding the mind, they’re qualified to be called a ‘mendicant who has attained extinguishment in this very life’.”
